children.value: The condition number measures how sensitive a problem is to small perturbations in the input. Large condition numbers signal potential trouble
—it’s a property of the mathematics, not the implementation.
Before we discuss algorithms and their errors, we need to understand:
some problems are inherently harder than others

children.value: . This isn’t a flaw in our algorithm—it’s the nature of the tangent function near its pole.
if my input is slightly wrong, how wrong might my output be?
Before measuring problem sensitivity, we need precise definitions of error.

children.value: f(x^*) = f(x + h) \approx f(x) + f'(x)(x - x^*)
children.html: f(x∗)=f(x+h)≈f(x)+f′(x)(x−x∗)f(x^*) = f(x + h) \approx f(x) + f'(x)(x - x^*)f(x∗)=f(x+h)≈f(x)+f′(x)(x−x∗)
f(x)−f(x∗)≈f′(x)(x−x∗)f(x) - f(x^*) \approx f'(x)(x - x^*)f(x)−f(x∗)≈f′(x)(x−x∗)

children.value: The condition number is a property of the
—it tells us the best possible accuracy any algorithm could achieve. But even well-conditioned problems can give bad results if we use a bad algorithm. That’s the subject of the
